sentence:
Chicago, IL - February 02, 2016 - Today, Zacks Equity Research discusses the Consumer Staples, including Kimberly-Clark Corp. ( KMB ), ConAgra Foods, Inc. ( CAG ), General Mills, Inc. ( GIS ) and Procter & Gamble ( PG )

The year 2015 turned out to be a mixed bag for the consumer staples sector.

It had a good start as consumer spending power improved amid a moderate economic recovery and improving job market, rising wages, cheaper fuel, improved business and renewed optimism as a result of the housing recovery.
However, the global scenario became challenging from the second quarter, weighed down by concerns about China and the strong U.S. dollar as a result of the Fed outlook.
U.S. stocks rebounded toward the end of the year when the Federal Reserve raised the interest rate by a quarter percentage point for the first time in nearly a decade.
Positive GDP and improving consumer confidence also signaled that the U.S. economy had recovered to a great extent - a positive for consumer staples.
However, the situation did not improve in China and remained sluggish, with currency devaluation and dwindling stocks continued to dampen investors' sentiment.
China's trading behavior did not even spare other emerging economies and blue-chip companies, thus impacting stocks with significant presence in emerging and developing markets.
Lowering crude oil prices is also negatively impacting commodity prices like copper.
Though lower oil prices increases consumer spending power, but it is also raising investors' fears that slackening global growth is drying up demand for energy and materials.

In addition to these global worries, continued appreciation of the U.S. dollar relative to most foreign currencies continues to weigh on earnings of U.S.-based staples companies with significant international operations.

Other risks include potential price wars, a competitive environment, slowdown in international markets, political turmoil in Russia, sluggishness in Japan and an unfavorable economic environment in Europe.
As the earnings season unfolds, investors need to make sure they are positioned well for the upcoming year.
We note that the U.S. economy has improved over the past year, though it is not completely insulated against China's market upheavals.
An improving labor market is also adding to consumers' willingness to buy.
Consumer Confidence -- a key determinant of the economy's health -- improved significantly in December.
According to the recent Conference Board data , the Consumer Confidence Index increased to 98.1 in January from the December reading of 96.3.
Industry experts believe that an optimistic view of the job market may have acted as a catalyst to consumer sentiment.
The Employment Trend Index increased in December and now stands at 129.33, up from 128.27 in November.
How Will the Players Fare This Earnings Season?

Among the industry players who have already reported, Kimberly-Clark Corp. ( KMB ) and ConAgra Foods, Inc. ( CAG ), posted negative earnings surprises of 1.4% and 1.7%, respectively, while General Mills, Inc. ( GIS ) reported in-line earnings.
In terms of revenues, Kimberly-Clark, ConAgra and General Mills missed estimates by 0.95%, 8.7%, 3.3%, respectively.

For Procter & Gamble ( PG ), earnings beat expectations while revenues missed it for the eighth consecutive quarter due to currency headwinds, volatile market conditions and retailer inventory reductions in markets facing currency devaluations.

Grappling with currency headwinds and inherent slower secular growth, these companies will likely have to be more innovative to attain better top-line growth while consistently finding ways to be more efficient and cost effective.
Now let us look into other consumer staple stocks that have the potential to beat estimates this earnings season, despite global worries.
There are quite a few companies in the consumer staples space.

To find out companies that are likely to beat expectations in their upcoming releases, we will narrow down the list of choices by looking at stocks with a favorable Zacks Rank of #1 (Strong Buy), #2 (Buy) or #3 (Hold) - and a positive Earnings ESP .
